Award.AwardTitle: Integrative Functions of Lipins in Energy Homeostasis
Award.AbstractNarration: Organisms keep energy reserves in the form of fats that are often stored in specialized fat tissues. Excessive fat storage in humans that may lead to obesity depends on an individual?s genetic background. Unfortunately, we know little about the genes that control fat metabolism and how they interact. This project will use the unique toolbox of fruit fly genetics to study a gene that is a central regulator of fat metabolism. Studies of this gene in mammals (such as humans and mice) are complicated by the presence of three closely related gene copies, whereas flies have only one copy. The project will generate mutant versions of the gene to study how it controls fat metabolism, and it will study how the gene itself is regulated in response to food intake. Results will improve our knowledge of pathways that regulate fat metabolism and storage. Since fundamental metabolic processes are very similar in insects and mammals, the results are likely to also lead to an improved knowledge of the genetic control of fat metabolism in humans. This is of importance because obesity in humans increases the risk for diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and cancer. The project will be carried out mostly by graduate and undergraduate students and, thus, contribute to the education of our next generation of scientists and innovators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project produced results that led to a better understanding of how adiposity is controlled by genes and signaling pathways that respond to nutrition. At the center of the study was the single protein of the lipin family in fruit flies, dLipin. dLipin and its counterparts in mammals are essential for fat synthesis in adipose tissue, but can also migrate into the cell nucleus to regulate gene expression. We created a dLipin mutant that completely lacked the fat-synthesizing ability of dLipin and found that this mutant was not viable, indicating that dLipin is required for normal development. Further, we used unique tools of fly genetics to show that pathways that respond to food intake and nutrients, the TORC1 and insulin pathways, control nuclear translocation of dLipin and its role in fat production. When nutrients are scarce and TORC1 activity is low, dLipin migrates into the cell nucleus to increase resistance of the organism against starvation. When insulin signaling is low, the ability of dLipin to produce fat is strongly reduced. Thus, dLipin responds differentially to two pathways that are known to control metabolic responses to nutritional intake. Interestingly, lowering the activity of dLipin led to a decrease in the tissue response to insulin and reduced cell growth, indicating that lower levels of dLipin can cause insulin resistance, which is a hallmark of type 2 diabetes. These data support association studies in mice and humans that have suggested a connection between lipins, glucose metabolism, and type 2 diabetes.

Most of the experimental work of this project was carried out by graduate and undergraduate students. Thus, the project provided these students with training in scientific research and prepared them for careers in academia and the medical field.
